newsitem.title: KENYA: Water shortage is in second week in Nairobi.
newsitem.headline: Water shortage is in second week in Nairobi.

text.p: Kenya's capital is suffering a second week of water shortages, another blow to residents hit by power rationing and poor roads, consumer groups said on Thursday.
Francis Orago, executive director of the Kenya Consumers Organisation, said such small things eroded investor confidence and undermined economic growth.
"We estimate that up to 1.5 million of Nairobi's estimated 2.5 million population are affected by the current water crisis," Orago told Reuters.
"Worse still, even if the shortages were not there, Nairobi no longer has clean water," said Orago, adding consumers were asked to boil city water before drinking.
The shortage began last week when pipes burst at Sasumua in central Kenya at a dam supplying 40 percent of the city's water. Nairobi City Council said at the time it would take a week to repair.
City Council Deputy Town Clerk Judy Munyiri said a private company was working on the water problem and supplies should be restored by the weekend.
The Federation of Kenya Employers said its members were complaining.

"People cannot shower or use house toilets. You have to travel for a distance to draw water by bucket," a spokesman said. "Company bosses have to pass through hotels to shower before proceeding to their offices. Too bad for everyone else."
Power has been rationed in Nairobi since November and authorities say that will continue until July.
Roads are in a poor state. Local government has launched a project to fill potholes, some in Nairobi's commercial district, and says it will take at least three years.
